title-group.article-title: Alkaloids with cholinesterase inhibitory activities from the bulbs of Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl

Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. (Amaryllidaceae)
Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. (Amaryllidaceae)

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Alkaloids with cholinesterase inhibitory activities from the bulbs of
Crinum
× amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl

sec.p:
Waraluck Chaichompoo a, b , Pornchai Rojsitthisak
a, b, * , Wachirachai Pabuprapap c , Yuttana Siriwattanasathien c , Pathumwadee Yotmanee c , Apichart Suksamrarn c

in Natural Products for Aging and Chronic Diseases , Chulalongkorn University , Bangkok , 10330, Thailand

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
C rinum
× amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl.
Alkaloids
Acetylcholinesterase
Butyrylcholinesterase
Molecular docking
ABSTRACT

Seven previously undescribed alkaloids, crinamabilines A–G, two non-alkaloidal compounds, crinamabidiene and 6-phenylpiperonyl alcohol, two first naturally occurring alkaloids, 3-epibuphanisine and (+)-1 β ,2 β -epoxy-epicrinine, together with nineteen known alkaloids, were isolated from the bulbs of
Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. Their
structures and absolute configurations were elucidated by NMR, MS and ECD spectroscopic techniques. Ungeremine displayed the most potent inhibitory activity against acetylcholinesterase (IC 50 0.21 μM), which was about 6-fold more active than the reference drug, galanthamine (IC 50 1.23 μM). Ungeremine also exhibited the strongest inhibitory activity against butyrylcholinesterase (IC 50 3.57 μM), which was comparable to galanthamine (IC 50 3.11 μM). The molecular docking studies were performed and were well in agreement with the experimental results.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Based on our preliminary screening of Thai medicinal plants with cholinesterase inhibition, we found that the active EtOAc and BuOH crude extracts of the bulbs of
C. amabile
showed inhibitory activities against AChE and BuChE with IC 50 ranging from 0.2 to 1.1 μg/mL and 1.2–2.3 μg/mL, respectively. These extracts were therefore subjected to column chromatography and led to the isolation of thirty compounds. The chemical structures of the isolated compounds were elucidated and characterized by spectroscopic ( 1 H and 13 C NMR, HR-TOFMS, optical rotation and ECD spectra) data.

Compound 2 was isolated as a white amorphous solid and was assigned a molecular formula of C 19 H 21 NO 6 as deduced by HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 360.1445 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441). The IR spectrum showed absorption bands of hydroxy (3400
a Assignments were based on 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY experiments.
b Partially overlapping signal.

Compound 3 was obtained as a white amorphous solid, which was deduced to have a molecular formula of C 19 H 21 NO 6 by the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 360.1439 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441). The IR spectrum displayed absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3399 cm 1 ), acetoxy ( 1738 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1642 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 928 cm 1 ) functionalities. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 3 ( Tables 1 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S32 S36) showed closely similar spectral features to those of compound 2 . The significant difference was the acetoxy signal ( δ H 2.20 and δ C 171.9) in the α -orientation, which is evident from the NOESY correlation of the benzylic proton H-6 ( δ H 6.63) and H-4a ( δ H 3.49, brdd, J = 13.0 and 3.7 Hz) (see Fig. 3 ). It should be mentioned that the relatively more down-field signal of H-6 β ( δ H 6.63) of compound 3 than that of the H-6 α ( δ H 6.14) of compound 2 was consistent with that reported previously (
). Furthermore, the α -oriented OAc group in compound 3 caused considerable downfield shift (0.47 ppm) of the H-12 endo and upfield shift (0.21 ppm) of the H-12 exo resonances compared with compound 1 . The absolute configuration of this compound was also determined from the ECD experiments that exhibited a similar negative Cotton effect at 250 nm (Δ ε 52.3) and a positive Cotton effect at 280 nm (Δ ε + 37.0) to those of compound 2 . The absolute configuration of 3 was confirmed as 3 S ,4a S ,5 R ,6 R ,10bR,11 R . Therefore, the structure of compound 3 was established as shown and this compound was named crinamabiline C.

Compound 4 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 332.1494 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492) was compatible with the molecular formula C 18 H 21 NO 5 . The IR spectrum exhibited absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3424 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1664 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 4 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S48 S53) were similar to those of compound 2 . The first significant difference was the presence of a pseudoequatorial methoxy proton ( δ H 3.38, s). The HMBC correlation between this methoxy proton with a carbon resonance at δ C 78.4 confirmed that the location of the methoxy group was C-3 (see Fig. 2 and Table S2 ). The magnitude of coupling constants between H-3ax ( δ H 4.00–4.05, m, W ½ = 20.8 Hz) and both H-4ax ( δ H 2.09, ddd, J = 13.7, 10.6 and 9.7 Hz) and H-4eq ( δ H 1.91, dddd, J = 13.7, 5.6, 3.0 and 0.7 Hz) were in agreement with the α -ethano bridge and an equatorial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-3. The difference of the large coupling constant (10.6 Hz) between H-3ax and H-4ax in compound 4 and between H-3eq and H-4ax (W ½ of H-3 was 11.8 Hz) in compound 2 was noted. The equatorial-orientation of the C-3 methoxy group was also established from the NOESY interaction of H-3 with H-4a ( δ H 3.36, brdd, J = 9.7 and 3.0 Hz) and correlations of H-4a with H-3 and H-4eq confirmed the axial-orientation of H-3 ( Fig. 3 ). In addition, the NOE difference experiments also confirmed the orientation of H-3. Thus, irradiation at the H-3 frequency of compound 4 resulted in key NOE enhancements of the H-4a and H-4eq signals (Fig. S167). The second main difference was the presence of a singlet proton at δ H 3.57 assignable to the pseudoaxial methoxy proton at C-6. This assignment was confirmed by the HMBC correlation of the 6-methoxy proton with C-6 ( δ C 97.8). Moreover, the NOESY relationship between H-6 ( δ H 4.47) and H-12 endo ( δ H 3.31, brdd, J = 14.1 and 7.0 Hz) indicated the α -orientation for H-6. The absolute configuration of 4 was also confirmed by the ECD experiments that exhibited a similar negative Cotton effect at 245 nm (Δ ε 16.7) and a positive Cotton effect at 292 nm (Δ ε + 18.6) to those of compound 2 . The absolute configuration of 4 was therefore elucidated as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 R and this compound was named crinamabiline D.

Compound 5 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The molecular formula of compound 5 was determined to be C 18 H 21 NO 5 based on the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 332.1496 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492). The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3419 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1652 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 936 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 5 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S65 S70) closely resembled those of 4 . The significant difference was the C-6 methoxy group was in the α -orientation, which was established by the NOESY experiment. The NOESY correlation between H-6 ( δ H 5.06) and H-4a ( δ H 3.29–3.32) confirmed the β -orientation of H-6 (see Fig. 3 ). It is noteworthy that the methoxy substituent exerted a similar effect to that of the acetoxy substituent in compound 3 . The α -oriented 6-OMe group in compound 5 caused a downfield shift (0.52 ppm) of the H-12 endo and an upfield shift (0.37 ppm) of the H-12 exo resonances compared with the β -oriented 6-OMe of compound 4 . The absolute configuration of this alkaloid was confirmed from the ECD experiments analogous to compound 4 with a similar negative Cotton effect at 245 nm (Δ ε 41.7) and a positive Cotton effect at 292 nm (Δ ε + 46.5). The absolute configuration of 5 was established as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 R ,10bR,11 R . On the basis of these data, the structure of compound 5 was elucidated as shown and was named crinamabiline E.

Compound 6 was isolated as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 402.1547 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 21 H 24 NO 7 , 402.1547) was compatible with the molecular formula C 21 H 23 NO 7 . The IR spectrum showed absorption bands of acetoxy ( 1738 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1622 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 6 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S81 S85) were similar to those of compound 4 . The significant difference was the presence of a highly deshielded benzylic proton as a singlet at δ H 6.15 and a carbon resonance at δ C 88.2, together with an acetoxy group ( δ H 2.10, and δ C 172.4 and δ C 21.7). The HMBC correlations between the benzylic proton and the acetoxy methyl proton and the carbonyl carbon resonance confirmed that the acetoxy group was located at C-6 ( Fig. 2 and Table S2 ). Another main difference was the presence of an additional acetoxy group ( δ H 2.00, and δ C 172.5 and 21.6) and this group should be placed at C-11 as evidenced by the highly deshielded methine signal at δ H 4.84–4.87. This was further supported by the HMBC interaction between the acetoxy methyl proton and H-11. Compound 6 exhibited a similar ECD spectrum as those of compound 4 with a similar negative Cotton effect at 252 nm (Δ ε 8.5) and a positive Cotton effect at 280 nm (Δ ε + 30.6), suggesting the same R -configuration at C-11. The absolute configuration of 6 was therefore concluded as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 R . Consequently, compound 6 was elucidated as shown and was named crinamabiline F.
a Assignments were based on 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY experiments.
b Partially overlapping signal.
c Overlapping signal.
a Assignments were based on, 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY
experiments. b Recorded in CDCl. 3 c Recorded in CD OD. 3 d Partially overlapping signal. e Partially overlapping signal. The signal was resolved into δ 4.02–4.07 (m,
H W ½ = 20.5 Hz, H-3) and δ H 3.85 (d, J = 17.0 Hz, H-6 β ) in CD 3 OD.

Compound 8 was isolated as a white amorphous solid with a sodiated molecular ion of the HR-TOFMS at m/z 283.0947 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 15 H 16 NaO 4 , 283.0940) and the NMR data have led to the assignment of the molecular formula C 15 H 16 O 4 . The IR spectrum revealed the absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3274 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1635 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 13 C NMR and DEPT-135 data ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S115 S116) showed the presence of fifteen carbons belonging to one methyl, six methine, three methylene and five quaternary carbons, suggesting the phenylcyclohexadiene analog (
). The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S112 S114) showed the presence of a 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted aromatic ring at δ H 6.93 and 6.59, which are assigned to H-2 and H-5, respectively. The singlet signal at δ H 5.91 is assignable to the methylenedioxy proton. The occurrences of two-coupled olefinic protons at δ H 6.14 (brd, J = 9.5 Hz) and 6.01 (brdd, J = 9.5 and 3.9 Hz), together with an olefinic proton at δ H 5.78 (dddd, J = 4.6, 4.2, 1.1 and 1.0 Hz) were ascribable to H-6 ′ , H-5 ′ and H-2 ′ , respectively. The presences of one highly deshielded methine signal at δ H 4.10 (dddd, J = 6.6, 6.6, 3.9 and 1.1 Hz) and one methyl proton at δ H 3.34 (s) were indicative of a methoxy group and the correlations of 4 ′ -OCH 3 with C-4 ′ ( δ C 73.0) and H-4 ′ with H-2 ′ and H-5 ′ confirmed the location of a methoxy group at C-4 ′ . The small coupling constants of H-4 ′ with H-3 ′ ( δ H 2.59, ddd, J = 6.6, 4.6 and 4.2 Hz) and H-5 ′ were in agreement with the axial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-4 ′ . The axial-orientation of the C-4 ′ methoxy group was also established from the NOESY correlation of H-4 ′ with H-5 ′ and correlations of H-5 ′ with H-6 ′ confirmed the equatorial-orientation of H-4 ′ ( Fig. 3 ). One oxygenated methylene proton appeared as a singlet at δ H 4.45, indicating the benzylic methylene group. In the HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 and Table S4 ), the α -H ( δ H 4.45, s) showed the correlations with C-1 ( δ C 136.6), C-6 ( δ C 136.0) and C-1 ′ ( δ C 134.0), whereas H-2 correlated with C-3 ( δ C 148.6), C-4 ( δ C 148.8), C-6 and α -C ( δ C 63.0). Moreover, the HMBC interactions between H-5 with C-1, C-3, C-4, C-6 and C-1 ′ were also observed. According to the above evidence, the structure of 8 was determined as 6-(4 ′ -methoxy-1 ′ ,5 ′ -cyclohexadienyl)piperonyl alcohol and was named crinamabidiene. The skeleton of compound
8 in
relation to those of the alkaloids isolated in this work has led to a postulate that this compound could possibly derive from the degradation of a constituent alkaloid present in
C. amabile
similar to the previous report for the degradation of other Amaryllidaceae alkaloids (
). More information is needed on whether the transformation has occurred by enzymatic or non-enzymatic means.

Compound 9 was isolated along with compound 8 . The molecular formula C 14 H 12 O 3 was deduced from the HR-TOFMS at m/z 251.0682 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 14 H 12 NaO 3 , 251.0678). The IR spectrum revealed the absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3393 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 932 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectra ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S128 S130) revealed the presence of the same piperonyl alcohol moiety as that of compound 8 . The presence of the aromatic proton signals at δ H 7.31 (m, 3H, H-3 ′ , H-4 ′ and H-5 ′ ) and δ H 7.38 (m, 2H, H-2 ′ and H-6 ′ ) has led to the conclusion that compound 9 is 6-phenylpiperonyl alcohol. In fact, this compound has been reported previously as an intermediate of chemical degradation of an alkaloid (
). Compound 9 should therefore be obtained from compound 8 by the elimination of methanol.
a Assignments were based on 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY experiments.
a Assignments were based on, 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY experiments.
b Recorded in CD OD.
3 c Recorded in CDCl.
a Data represent as IC values in μM ± S.D. of three independent experiments. 50 b Inactive at 0.1 mg/mL.
c Galanthamine was used as the reference drug.

The binding interaction of the alkaloid
29 in
the active site of AChE and BuChE has been studied. A molecular docking study was performed using Autodock 4.2 software to investigate the binding affinity of alkaloid 29 against AChE and BuChE by docking to its binding pocket. The relevance of the docking parameters was verified by re-docking galanthamine and tacrine to their binding sites in AChE and BuChE, respectively. The docking models of the original drugs were well aligned with their crystal structures, indicating that the setting parameters were appropriate for this study ( Fig. 5A and D ). The binding interaction, binding energy (BE, kcal/mol) and % conformation (%C) of alkaloid 29 and galantamine to the target proteins are summarized in Table S5 . The docking results suggested that alkaloid 29 has a better binding affinity to AChE than galanthamine and is equally proportional at BuChE. The strong binding interaction with key residues in the receptor binding domain was also considered as criteria in determining the potential inhibitor. Alkaloid 29 showed good binding affinity values of 8.26 kcal/ mol with a high %C of 88.5. Fig. 5C shows that compound 29 was well occupied in the active gorge of AChE at a different subsite from that of galanthamine. It was able to form two hydrogen bonds at the acyl pocket with R296 (distance of 1.75 Å) and S293 (distance of 2.11 Å) and two pi-pi interactions with Y124 and W286 at the peripheral anionic site (distances of 5.81, 5.67 Å for Y124 and 5.22 and 5.38 Å for W286), while two hydrogen bonds with the oxygen anion cavity G120 (distance of 2.84 Å) and the anionic site E202 (distance of 1.73 Å) and a pi-alkyl interaction of the oxygen anion cavity G121 (distance of 3.92 Å) were found for the galanthamine ( Fig. 5B ). It can be seen that the alkaloid 29 is not only more hydrophobic to AChE, but also has shorter hydrogen bonding distances. Therefore, it could bind to AChE better than galanthamine, which is consistent with the experimental IC 50 value. Furthermore, when compound 29 was considered in the BuChE binding pocket, it was found to bind at the same subsite as galanthamine. This alkaloid was stabilized by two pi-pi interactions with W82 (5.34 and 4.99 Å) and two hydrogen bonds with Y128 and D70 (distances of 1.80 and 2.05 Å, respectively) ( Fig. 5F ). It has a proportional binding affinity to the BuChE binding pocket as galanthamine, which forms two hydrogen bonds with the catalytic triad residue Y440 (1.86 and 1.91 Å) and two pi-pi interactions with the catalytic anionic site W82 (3.68 and 4.36 Å) ( Fig. 5E ). This is likewise the IC 50 values found in the experiment.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In conclusion, seven undescribed alkaloids ( 1–7 ), two undescribed analogs ( 8 and 9 ) and two first naturally occurring alkaloids ( 10 and 11 ), together with nineteen known alkaloids ( 12–30 ), have been isolated from
C. amabile
bulbs. Compound 29 exhibited the most potent acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitory activity, which was about 6-fold more active than galanthamine, the reference drug. Molecular docking studies are well in agreement with the experimental results. The alkaloid 29 may serve as a lead compound for anti-AChE drug development.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
The bulbs of
Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. (Amaryllidaceae)
were collected from Bang Kruai District , Nonthaburi Province , Thailand (13 ◦ 80 ′ 35.7 ′′ N, 100 ◦ 41 ′ 77.4 ′′ E) in
January 2020
and the plant species was identified by Assoc. Prof. Nopporn Dumrongsiri , Ramkhamhaeng University. A voucher specimen is deposited at the Faculty of Science , Ramkhamhaeng University , Thailand ( Apichart Suksamrarn, No. 103)
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
The fresh bulbs of
C. × amabile
( 1.5 kg ) were minced and macerated with MeOH (5 × 20 L) at room temperature for 72 h in each extraction. The filtered solution was evaporated in vacuo to yield the crude MeOH extract ( 50.5 g ). The MeOH extract was suspended in 1 L distilled water and sequentially partitioned with n -hexane, EtOAc, and n -BuOH (3 × 1 L for each solvent) to give the hexane ( 0.8 g ), EtOAc (3.0 g) and butanol (36.0 g) extracts, respectively. The EtOAc and butanol extracts gave a positive test to Dragendorff’ s reagent.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Isolation of the compounds from the EtOAc extract
sec.p: The crude EtOAc extract ( 2.9 g ) was fractionated by column chromatography using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, and MeOH with increasing amounts of the more polar solvent. The eluates were examined by TLC and five combined fractions (A1–A5) were obtained. Fraction A1 ( 232.8 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography eluting with an isocratic condition of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2, v/v) to give compound 6 ( 2.4 mg ). Fraction A2 ( 1.4 g ) was column chromatographed using CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:3, v/v) as eluent to provide three subfractions (A2.1–A2.3). Subfraction A2.1 ( 86.7 mg ) was chromatographed on a silica gel column eluting with hexane–EtOAc (5:95, v/v) to yield compound 22 ( 1.6 mg ). Subfraction A2.2 ( 198.1 mg ) was further subjected to column chromatography using hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:4, v/v) as eluent to yield compounds 10 (1.0 mg) and 12 ( 2.2 mg ). Subfraction A2.3 (1.0 g) was chromatographed on silica gel column eluting with hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:5, v/v) to provide compound 20 ( 16.4 mg ). Fraction A3 ( 165.5 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography (column diameter 1 cm , with a 20 cm height of the packing material) eluting with a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2–100:5, v/v) to yield compounds 2 ( 1.1 mg ) and 3 ( 1.4 mg ). Fraction A4 (1.0 g) was further chromatographed by silica gel column eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:4, v/v, with ca 0.5 mL volume for each fraction) to give compounds 18 ( 11.4 mg ) and 24 ( 4.5 mg ). Compound 28 (4.0 mg) was obtained after purification of fraction A5 ( 66.2 mg ) by silica column chromatography using CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:8, v/v) as eluent.

sec.title: 4.3.2. Isolation of the compounds from the BuOH extract
sec.p: The crude BuOH extract (29.0 g) was fractionated by column chromatography using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, and MeOH with increasing amounts of the more polar solvent. The eluates were examined by TLC and seven combined fractions (B1–B7) were obtained. Fraction B1 ( 12.7 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography eluting with a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2–100:4, v/v) to yield compounds 8 (1.0 mg), 9 ( 0.2 mg ) and 15 (5.0 mg). Fraction B2 ( 16.6 mg ) was repeatedly chromatographed on a silica gel column in a similar manner to that employed for the isolation of compound 2 from compound 3 , with hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:6, v/v) as eluent, to afford compounds 4 ( 0.8 mg ), 5 ( 0.5 mg ) and 23 ( 1.3 mg ). Fraction B3 ( 186.9 mg ) was further separated by silica column chromatography, using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:6–100:8, v/v) to provide compounds 11 ( 1.9 mg ), 16 ( 12.5 mg ), 19 ( 4.3 mg ) and 26 ( 10.5 mg ). Fraction B4 ( 8.4 g ) was chromatographed on silica column eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:10, v/v) to give compounds 21 ( 1.4 mg ), 25 (130.0 mg), 27 ( 20.3 mg ) and 30 ( 0.8 mg ). Fraction B5 (144.0 mg) was similarly chromatographed eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:12, v/v) to give compound 7 ( 22.5 mg ). Reversed-phase column chromatography of fraction B6 ( 78.7 mg ) using RP-18 column, with MeOH–H 2 O (6:4, v/v) as eluting solvent, furnished compounds 1 ( 1.5 mg ), 13 ( 0.8 mg ), 14 ( 0.8 mg ) and 17 ( 3.2 mg ). Column chromatography of fraction B7 ( 167.8 mg ) eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:30, v/v) afforded compound 29 (5.0 mg).

sec.title: 4.4.1. Crinamabiline A (1)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 25 16.1 (c 0.95, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 244 (34.5), 294 (+ 31.3) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3253, 2893, 1654, 1483, 1300, 1237, 1032, 931 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 1 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 288.1243 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 16 H 18 NO 4 , 288.1230).

sec.title: 4.4.2. Crinamabiline B (2)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 20.3 ( c 0.20, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 245 (35.0), 290 (+ 35.6) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3400, 2982, 1735, 1644, 1483, 1359, 1251, 1071, 1036, 933 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 1 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 360.1445 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441).

sec.title: 4.4.3. Crinamabiline C (3)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 24 38.0 ( c 0.03, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 250 (52.3), 280 (+ 37.0) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3399, 2986, 1738, 1642, 1483, 1258, 1069, 1037, 928 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 1 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 360.1439 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441).

sec.title: 4.4.4. Crinamabiline D (4)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 25 + 73.0 ( c 0.04, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 245 (16.7), 292 (+ 18.6) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3424, 2933, 1664, 1481, 1327, 1256, 1088, 1037, 931 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 332.1494 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492).

sec.title: 4.4.5. Crinamabiline E (5)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D + 94.9 ( c 0.13, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 245 (41.7), 292 (+ 46.5) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3419, 2972, 1652, 1482, 1319, 1243, 1096, 1037, 936 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 332.1496 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492).

sec.title: 4.4.6. Crinamabiline F (6)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 25 + 33.8 ( c 0.19, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 252 (8.5), 280 (+ 30.6) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 2987, 1738, 1622, 1483, 1370, 1237, 1096, 1034, 931 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 402.1547 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 21 H 24 NO 7 , 402.1547).

sec.title: 4.4.7. Crinamabiline G (7)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 25 + 144.0 ( c 0.25, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 246 (33.2), 280 (+ 20.8) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3356, 2938, 1482, 1378, 1240, 1093, 1037, 933 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CDCl 3 ), see Tables 3 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 320.1491 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 17 H 22 NO 5 , 320.1492).

sec.title: 4.4.8. Crinamabidiene (8)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 59.5 ( c 0.08, MeOH); IR (ATR) ν max 3274, 2896, 1635, 1483, 1301, 1233, 1035, 931 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Table 4 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 283.0947 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 15 H 16 NaO 4 , 283.0940).

sec.title: 4.4.9. 6-Phenylpiperonyl alcohol (9)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; IR (ATR) ν max 3393, 2928, 1601, 1551, 1480, 1227, 1039, 932 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Table 4 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 251.0682 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 14 H 12 NaO 3 , 251.0678).

sec.title: 4.4.10. 3-Epibuphanisine (10)
sec.p: White amorphous solid; [ α ] D 25 + 35.1 ( c 0.38, EtOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 244 (+ 24.0), 294 (22.8) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 2932, 1644, 1481, 1319, 1232, 1087, 1036, 932 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CDCl 3 ), see Tables 3 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 286.1432 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 17 H 20 NO 3 , 286.1437).

White amorphous solid; [ α ] D + 89.1 ( c 0.07, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 249 (+ 31.5), 279 (9.1) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3356, 2895, 1483, 1284, 1238, 1037, 934 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data (CD 3 OD), see Tables 3 and 5 ; HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) m/z 288.1255 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 16 H 18 NO 4 , 288.1230).

sec.title: 4.5. Anti-cholinesterase activities assay
4.6. Molecular docking calculations
Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data availability
No data was used for the research described in the article.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: The authors express gratitude to the Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund for Postdoctoral Fellowship, Chulalongkorn University (W.C.) and for the Center of Excellence in Natural Products for Ageing and Chronic Diseases, Chulalongkorn University (GCE 6503433003-1, P.R.). Support from the Center of Excellence for Innovation in Chemistry, Ministry of Higher Education, Science, Research and Innovation is gratefully acknowledged (A.S.).

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113473.
